awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Brain, Biology, and Behavior Over the Transition to Fatherhood
awd_abstract_narration:
Father involvement in families benefits children across the lifespan. For example, children with involved fathers show improvements in school readiness, physical health, peer relationships, resilience to psychopathology, and long-term economic and occupational outcomes. However, surprisingly little is known about the factors that predict whether and how fathers successfully transition to parenthood. Like mothers, fathers are affected both psychologically and physiologically by the arrival of a new child. For example, expectant and new fathers experience hormonal changes, and the structure and activity in their brains change as well. This project charts changes in individual fathers-to-be over time prior to and then after their first child is born, and explores which aspects of hormonal and brain changes are most likely to lead to positive parenting influences that optimize their babies' development. 

The HATCH (Hormones Across the Transition to Parenthood) study seeks to understand how fathers' brains and bodies prepare to parent. Expectant opposite-sex couples (all first-time parents) will complete five assessments: in-person prenatal (mid-to-late pregnancy); perinatal (within 1-2 days of birth), and postpartum (six months after birth) visits; and additional follow-up questionnaires at 3 months and one year after birth. Cortisol, testosterone, oxytocin, and prolactin will be sampled from the father and mother at each visit. These allow tracking of individual patterns of hormonal change over time, and hormonal synchrony within couples. The investigator will also collect neural data through a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanning protocol that includes a high-resolution structural scan and resting state scan to assess changes in brain structure and connectivity, and several functional tasks that assess social cognition. Outcomes related to parenting, couple relationship quality, and infant health and development will be measured through videotaped, in-lab interactions as well as through self-report questionnaires. This project will be the largest study of hormones in new parents to date, and the first study to collect longitudinal structural and functional MRI data from fathers before and after their child's birth.  The opportunity to educate parents regarding parenting and its hormonal and neural implications also makes valuable contributions.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the biological and neural underpinnings of fathers' preparation for parenthood. We assembled a corpus of data from 100 families followed from pregnancy across the first year postpartum, with data collections waves occuring prenatally, at birth, and at 3, 6, and 12 months following birth. This includes 42 fathers from whom we acquired neuroimaging data. We are now launching a seven-year follow-up to bring families back to the lab when their children are entering grade school. We have published over 20 peer-reviewed manuscripts reporting on the results of this study and presented this work at many scientific conferences. For example, in a paper published in American Psychologist, I argued that the transition to parenthood is a critical window for health and a potential inflection point for health disparities. This paper, which has been cited 120 times, reviewed literature on sleep, stress, health behaviors, hormonal change, and neuroplasticity in new parents, and connected these processes to the heightened risk of mood disorders, obesity, and inflammation during this time. I also wrote a theory/review paper for Health Psychology Review exploring mechanisms that might contribute to men's weight gain over the transition to parenthood and, with my graduate student Sofia Cardenas, published a review on expectant fathers' contributions to infant health. We also published a paper for a special issue of Biological Psychology focused on perinatal mood disorders that reported on associations between our prenatal oxytocin data and women's anxiety and depression, making a methodological contribution to the oxytocin literature by comparing two approaches to plasma oxytocin immunoassay. My graduate student Mona Khaled and I also published a paper that links couples' observationally coded conflict behavior with their childbirth experience (using both subjective and objective measures of birth, including medical complications recorded in hospital charts). Specifically, we found that couples who engaged in more negative conflict behavior in pregnancy subsequently had more stressful and more medically risky births. This is the first paper to look at couple relationship behavior as a predictor of birth experiences. We have also published results of our fathering brain study, such as papers finding that fathers' responses to a neuroimaging task of mentalizing abilities were linked with their prenatal oxytocin levels and predicted their postpartum parenting attitudes; a paper finding that fathers' neural responses to infant cry tracked with their testosterone levels; and a paper finding that fathers' prenatal resting state connectivity predicted their postpartum parenting behaviors. I have a new paper in preparation reporting that changes in hippocampal volume over the transition to fatherhood are associated with parenting stress and bonding in new fathers. We have published additional work on how father-infant touch predicts father oxytocin levels, and finding that access to paid paternity leave predicts better couple mental health in new parenthood. This project should yield many more publications and presentations in the future. We have also engaged extensively with the public, publishing op-eds and popular press articles describing this research.

A total of 13 graduate students have participated in data collection, analysis, and publication related to this project, making it a springboard for training new researchers. This includes 10 doctoral students in USC's clinical psychology program, of whom four have now completed their Ph.Ds; two students in USC's Neuroscience Graduate Program, and one Fulbright student in Neuroscience. Six lab managers have also worked on this project, of whom three are now in graduate or medical school, and several dozen undergraduates. We have prioritized training traditionally underrepresented and first-generation students.
